AUTHOR: David Miller

ABSTRACT:
The Tanner lectures have been given in an unbroken series stretching back to 1980 and many eminent philosophers and intellectuals have delivered them.  They were established to explore human values in a broad sense, but many of my predecessors have wanted not just to explore the meaning of values in themselves, but to consider their practical implications for how we should live, as individuals, or collectively together in societies.  My aim is to follow in their footsteps by addressing one very big practical issue that faces us collectively, namely humanly induced climate change and the steps we must now take to combat it.  I should say at once that I come to this issue neither as a scientist nor as policy-maker but as a political philosopher.  In other words, I shall not be entering into the many important and detailed debates about, for example, the rate at which global warming is currently occurring, or about the reduced level of greenhouse gas emissions that we need to achieve in order to halt the process.
